ThingDef.label: FN FAL X8E5
ThingDef.description:
Caliber: 7.62x51mm NATO. 20-round detachable mag. Select-Fire.
A .308 caliber automatic rifle and one of the earliest proper variants of the FN FAL. Tested in 1953 and 1954, the Belgian FAL weas selected for large scale trialing following the American mandate that the T65 (.308 Winchester, later 7.62x51mm NATO) cartridge be adopted as NATO standard

Britain had experimented with the FAL and its predecessors (in .280 caliber) in trials conducted from 1949 through 1951, but ultimately pressed the domestic bullpup EM-2 (also in .280 caliber) design into service. The EM-2, however, proved difficult to adapt to the .308 cartridge standardized not long after, forcing the military to turn to alternative designs. The FAL utilized the new cartridge efficiently, and thus, various different makes were tested as the "X8" series.

The X8s performed admirably, but numerous changes were made to the design that would ultimately be accepted as the L1A1 in 1954 - notably, the manufacturing specifications were changed from metric to British imperial measurements, and most L1A1s were built as semi-auto locked weapons.
